story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSir,I would like to commend the local Scottish Ambulance Service paramedic teams who assisted me recently when, not acting my age # I dislocated a replacement hip.The accident happened in a particularly inaccessible part of my garden on an unstable river bank enclosed by overgrown shrubs and trees.Malcolm McDonald, the sht leader and David Payne, assisted by Inveraray paramedics David Gowans and Nicola Fraser, not only extricated me in a safe and professional manner, but managed to transport me with great care and minimal pain to the ambulance.I am also grateful to the accident and emergency staff at the Mid Argyll Hospital and medical care centre, where I was promptly x-rayed and assessed. The decision was taken to send me to the Royal Alexandra Hospital in Paisley, and Neil Newman and Billy McArthur drove very carefully on the ersion route to Paisley, avoiding the recently damagedRest and be Thankful route.I am grateful to all those who delivered care to such a high standard, ensuring that my recovery was so successful after excellent treatment at the RAH.Jeremy Houston, PoltallochSir,As I read Councillor Alastair Redman’s letter in the August  edition of the Advertiser I thought how sad it is that a young man should always have such a pessimistic and depressing outlook that he chooses to share regularly with your readers.While we live through a pandemic we have seen the very best in people in our communities working to support and care for each other.Only last week the council publicly thanked the thousands of volunteers for their amazing efforts during the past months.The volunteers throughout our communities worked tirelessly and optimistically, always offering encouragement and kindness helping those who were at home to stay positive during such an anxious time.Local businesses provided an excellent service and continue to do so, enabling people to shop locally without making long journeys.If Councillor Redman cannot see the confident and positive support in all of our communities perhaps he should book an eye test, and he most certainly doesn’t have to travel to Barnard Castle to visit an optician.Councillor Anne Horn, TarbertSir,I was delighted to see the piece in a recent issue of the Argyllshire Advertiser featuring a reader from Tayvallich, setting out his case for #Time for Change#. I share many of his concerns, and commend the series of articles.It would be good to hear from a range of Argyll and Bute residents with their ideas for how we get from #here# towards a better #there#. My personal pet project would be an Argyll and Bute Citizens’ Assembly, that would bring people together to generate real strategies to bring about just and #green# change for our area.A good start would be better transport links, via enhanced road and ferry services.A permanent solution to the Rest and be Thankful would be welcome, of course, but it was really heartening to see how Western Ferries rose to the challenge on Friday Auust .  They magicked away that endless queue at Gourock with great patience and goodwill and double service, showing what can be done.Mary MacCallum Sullivan, ArdrishaigSir,Following the latest landslide and road closure at the Rest and be Thankful, once again the road closure signs were placed at the wrong place on the Arrochar side.Having spoken to several of the local businesses owners, the main issue around the signs are they are too far away from the incident. There are information signs from Balloch to Tarbet advising of the closure at the Rest.Surely moving the signs to Ardgartan would make more sense. Should anyone have to turn then there is ample space to do this. We cannot continue to render two villages effectively closed in case someone has failed to read the signs or cannot turn.Transport Scotland and BEAR Scotland must guarantee that the signs will not be put back in the same place when further disruption occurs, and it will.Jane Ireland, Slanj restaurant, Tarbet

title: enjoy cowal highland gathering in the comfort of your own home
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsWith just days to go until one of Scotland’s favourite events takes the virtual stage for the first time, Cowal Highland Gathering’s organisers are preparing to unveil a packed programme to a worldwide audience.Cowal’s Virtual Highland Gathering is an ambitious three-day event which mirrors as closely as possible the programme of the gathering itself.Kicking off on Thursday August , Cowal’s Virtual Gathering features a host of exclusive interviews and performances, together with a look back at some of the highlights of the -year-old event.The Gathering’s Friday night gig is back too, with the Gig at the Gathering Unplugged going live from pm. With some of the gathering’s most popular bands, including Skerryvore, Tide Lines and Heron Valley talking and performing, the spirit of the event will be very much alive in a year where all summer events were cancelled.Pipe band, Highland dancing and heavy athletics fans will also be catered for with archive footage and exclusive interviews with some of the biggest names in their field.Cowal Highland Gathering Chairman Ronnie Cairns is looking forward to seeing how people around the world celebrate the World’s Most Spectacular Highland Gathering, saying: #We were devastated at having to cancel this year’s gathering, but we’ve been working hard over the last few months to put together a virtual celebration which not only honours our historic event, but captures the heart of the gathering.#It is our privilege to bring the gathering into homes around the world, we hope people enjoy what we’ve got to offer, they marvel at our dancers, are stirred by our pipe bands and enthralled by our heavy athletes.#We don’t want people to simply sit and watch Cowal’s Virtual Gathering, we want them to be a part of it. Whether it’s putting on their trainers and running or walking in our Virtual K or enjoying a dram with our Saturday ceilidh band, we’d love people to get involved and send us their photos of how they’re enjoying their Virtual Gathering experience.#Cowal Highland Gathering is all about us gathering together in one place, and this year we are taking that one step further, coming together in a virtual space, which for three days we are turning tartan.#This year’s virtual edition of the gathering is supported through EventScotland, part of VisitScotland’s events directorate, through its international events programme.Paul Bush OBE, Director of Events at VisitScotland, said: #The Cowal Highland Gathering is one of the highlights of the Highland Games calendar, and while it is disappointing it won’t be taking place in its traditional form, we are delighted to be supporting this year’s innovative virtual edition.#The three-day online programme has a lot to offer, and it’s great to see that through performances, exclusive interviews and sporting challenges, audiences from around the world can still experience and join in the spectacle of the gathering from the comfort of their own homes.#Cowal’s Virtual Gathering will run on Cowal Highland Gathering’s Facebook page and YouTube channel from Thursday August  until Saturday August .For more details email info@cowalgathering or visit www.cowalgathering

To date there have been  productions and counting, . million views worldwide, , followers from  countries, and  traditional Scottish musician members.#We now have our own websitewhich hosts all of our content, news and will act as a directory for musicians, bands and tutors to promote their talents and services for free # which will also be shared promoted through our social media on a weekly basis,# added Martin.#Our Season One Tunebook is almost ready, hopefully the first in a collection of books that will coincide with our productions, allowing learners to play along with the existing videos and for pro am musicians to play for dancing as the tunes are organised into sets.#The productions will continue over the  months so long as there are willing musicians to share their talents, with competitions and virtual events planned for the near future.#One side-project that I am personally very excited about is Tunes TV, an online documentary series that is in development ,# said Martin.#My hope is that we can produce a contemporary, cinematic and engaging series that captures fresh perspectives and turns the spotlight on Scotland#s hidden musical talents, all whilst introducing the world of Scottish traditional music to a new generation.#By the end of the -month development period, we hope to achieve all of our goals, whilst setting the foundations to create our very own Tunes in the Hoose Festival, so that the  can be self-sustained and continue to grow.#Visit  www.facebook TunesInTheHoose

story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsThere was concern this week after a number of northern bottlenose whales were seen in the Firth of Clyde and an Argyll sea loch.The animals were spotted off Greenock and earlier this week in the upper reaches of Loch Goil.The northern bottlenose whale is an ocean species reaching aof around  metres and growing to seven and a half tonnes. They can e to over ,m depth and stay submerged for up to two hours hunting deep-water squid. Fish such as herring, prawns, sea cucumbers and starfish may also form part of their diet.Whatever has drawn them to the inshore waters of Scotland#s west coast, experts are worried that strandings could occur. Vet Catriona MacIntyre of Bute and Cowal Vets was monitoring the situation on behalf of the British Divers Marine Le Rescue group. She said: #These deep sea species are unfortunately a stranding risk.#By Wednesday of this week, the whales had moved towards the southern reaches of Loch Goil near Carrick Castle, the hope being that they would head back out to sea from the Firth of Clyde.After a long period of lobbying, businesses in Arrochar and Tarbet celebrated last week as the authorities relented and agreed to relocate #road closed# signs relating to closures around the A Rest and be Thankful.Many business managers have complained that the positioning of the ersion signs at the A A junction at Tarbet has damaged their revenue as potential customers believe the villages of Arrochar, Tarbet and Succoth to be cut off and inaccessible.Prominent in the campaign to have the signs moved have been Jane Ireland of the Slanj restaurant and Cristina Sanchez-Naro of Ashfield House guest house.Jane and Cristina announced on August : #After much lobbying and [many] conversations a trial period has been agreed. The signs will be relocated to Succoth on a trial period of four weeks.#Thanks must go to everyone who supported the relocation but especially to Councillor Shonny Paterson, Jackie Baillie MSP, Maurice Corry MSP and Brendan O# Hara MP.#Now to start the campaign to find a permanent solution for the Rest.#Radio and TV presenter John Beattie enjoyed a staycation break on the beautul island of Islay last week.The former Scotland and British Lions rugby player posted videos of the island#s fantastic beaches on Twitter, posting: #It was actually wonderful, restful, and relaxing to holiday on Islay and stay in Scotland this year.He continued : #And by the way, Islay is the best Scottish island#fact.#But his trip home was made more eventful than expected, as he explained on Twitter on Monday August : #After an amazing holiday on Islay. Someone in Inveraray told the police I’d been drinking beer at the harbour last night before jumping back in my car again. They pulled me over blue lights etc on Loch Lomondside.Mr Beattie added: #The reading was zero. I was using up an alcohol-free bottle with excellent fish and chips. So, back to work today.#

title: extension planned to skipness school consultation
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsTHE saga surrounding the future of Skipness Primary School in Kintyre looks set to continue until almost the end of the year.Argyll and Bute Council has plans to continue the consultation on the closure-threatened school’s future until December .The authority also intends to hold a public meeting on the future of the school once COVID- restrictions allow mass gatherings.The  school has been mothballed since October , with no new pupils enrolled. A public meeting was due to be held on May , but was cancelled due to the pandemic.The community services committee was asked to approve continuing the consultation when it met on Thursday August .A report by executive director Douglas Hendry said: #The original six week consultation period commenced on March  and was due to end at close of business on May , in order to meet the statutory requirements and include at least  school days.#A public meeting was also arranged for May  in Skipness Village Hall.#However, shortly after commencement of the consultation the coronavirus outbreak caused schools to be closed and restrictions on public gatherings were enforced as part of the lockdown measures.#It was therefore clear that the consultation exercise would not be able to proceed as originally planned.#At its meeting on April , the business continuity committee agreed to officers# proposals to extend the consultation period from May  to August  and to cancel the public meeting scheduled for May , with a new date to be set once the regulations imposing restrictions of public gatherings allow it to proceed.#Mr Hendry added: #Given the current Covid- pandemic this report sets out proposals to further extend the ongoing statutory consultation exercise with regard to the proposal to close Skipness Primary School and to hold a rearranged public meeting once the UK Scottish Government restrictions on public assemblies allow it to proceed.#

title: heathers treks tranquil lochs and magical isles
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsThis delightful walk – and the accompanying extensions for those who wish to walk further # encompasses calm tranquility, intriguing history and a wonderful array of plants and wildle.The area is famed for its beavers, first released here in  its woodlands and incredible geology.It is as beautul in winter light as it is on a balmy summer’s day.Historical points of interest include the old settlement, cross and well at Kilmory Oib and the ruins of Coille BharrMill.To make the most of the walk it is worth visiting the Faery Isles section when the tide is out and the freshwater lochs later in the dayyou wish to have the chance of spotting a beaver. Note the cross and well at its centre, often a mass of watercress .The described route and accompanying information are there to be used as a guide and do not replace the use of map and compass and the skills required to use them. title: photographer-natalie-luke-gives-1-400-coldstream-primary
story: A BORDERS photographer has raised more than pound, for a local primary school after completing her ldquoLockdown Doorstep Portraits Challenge.Natalie Luke, , from Duns, started taking pictures of people on their front doorsteps in May.She has now used the income to give a donation of pound, to Coldstream Primary School.ldquoWhen I handed over the cheque I was very excited and happy, knowing that the money raised was being donated to a wonderful place, Miss Luke told the Border .When the UK went into lockdown in March, Miss Luke was forced to close her photography business, Natalie Luke Photography, as summer events were cancelled or postponed.:The Borders woman rowing across the Atlantic in a boat made of plastic bottlesBut when restrictions began to ease, she saw an opportunity to dust off her camera."Instead of being stuck in the house, I thought I would pick up my camera again and help raise some money for a good cause, said Miss Luke.She added: "By the time I started the challenge in May the country had been in lockdown for two months, so I hoped it would give the local community something to look forward to."We have never had to experience anything like this before in our lives."Documenting it and keeping photographs will allow us to reflect back on those memories in years to come."From the very beginning it was planned to be a fundraiser and I knew I wanted to raise money for a good cause within my local community."After setting up her business five years ago, Miss Luke has photographed some of the key moments in many peoplersquos lives, including baby portraits, family photos and weddings.One of the benefits of launching her Lockdown Doorstep Portraits Challenge was that she was able to revisit previous clients, albeit in a dferent way."A large portion of my business is based around newborns, children and family photography and it was lovely to see old and new clients being eager to participate, said Miss Luke."I couldnt imagine what all the children must have been experiencing during the lockdown.ldquoThey wouldnt have properly understood why they couldnt go to school to learn, see their friends and family members, go out and play and just be kids.:Why this Peebles mum has organised her own half marathonOn August , Miss Luke visited Coldstream Primary School to hand over a super-sized cheque to head teacher Chris Reid.Miss Luke said: "Coldstream Primary School is where all the children attend and they do an amazing job with their education, so they were the perfect fit for the donation.In a Facebook post on the schools page, Mr Reid said: "A huge thank you to Natalie Luke Photography who handed the school a cheque for pound,."This was raised doing her doorstep photographs."Thank you to all who helped by getting their photos taken."

title: 10-scottish-museums-back-business-visit-weekend
story: NOW, are you sure yoursquove got everything  Mask  Hand-sanitiser  Thirst for learning  Yes  I think wersquore good to go then.While we are still under the shadow of the virus, some things are beginning to come back, museums among them.The last few days has seen the reopening of both the National Museum of Scotland and Kelvingrove Museum.And while access is controlled and there are limitations on where you can go, after months in lockdown the chance to visit your favourite museumis surely to be welcomed.Herersquos  you might like to visit soon...And remember to wear that mask when yoursquore indoors.National Museum of Scotland, EdinburghReopened on Wednesday on reduced hours , the National Museum of Scotland is once again the perfect retreat for those seeking refuge from the temperamental Edinburgh weather. Pre-booked timed entry, mandatory face coverings and one-way routes are all now in operation as the museum tries totonormal. Entrance will be by the west door on Chambers Street.The museumrsquos reopening will be phased in. The entrance hall and level one are now open to visitors, but rooms with a high number of interactive displays, including the Imagine and Explore galleries, remain closed for the moment.Inevitably, the museum has had to postpone a number of special exhibitions, but it is home to Scotlandrsquos Precious Seas, an exhibition that explores the nationrsquos erse sea le and the effect climate change is having on our maritime environment. Itrsquos part of the Year of Coasts and Waters.Visit nms.ac.ukfor more details and to book entryKelvingrove Museum, GlasgowPre-booking is also required for Kelvingrove which has reopened its doors to the public from am to pm daily. Tickets will be available up to two weeks in advance, with a maximum of six visitors for each booking, all from the same family. Entry will be timed and will allow visitors a two-hour slot. A one-way system has been introduced, but most of the main gallery spaces are open. Masks are required and there will be no catering facilities. But the toilets are open. Entrance is by the carpark side.That only leaves one question. Whatrsquos the first thing yoursquore going to visit when you get back in  Are you there for the ancient Egyptian artefacts or for a catch-up with the work of Charles Rennie Mackintosh PS, the Riverside Museum is reopening on August . Put it in your diary.For more information and to book tickets, visit glasgowmuseumsNational Museum of Flight, East FortuneBooking in advance for timed entry is required for the National Museum of Flight in East Fortune. But at least you donrsquot need to self-quarantine when you get off the planes here. Some buildings are still closed unfortunately, but the Concorde Experience, the Parachute Store and the civil and military aviation hangars are all open, as well as the shop and cafe. One-way routes are in use.And, of course, the airfield itself is open, which means you can have a look inside the planes ndash therersquos a Vulcan, a Comet and a BAC - ndash on display. No passports required.Visit nms.ac.uk national-museum-of-flightfor details and bookings.The McManus art gallery and museum, DundeeNamed Scotlandrsquos best visitor attraction not long before lockdown, the McManus reopened on Thursday and remains one of the most reliable boltholes in Dundee .Now open daily from Tuesday to Saturday, am to pm, there is no booking necessary and exhibitions are free. The cafeacute has reopened with social distancing measures and the shop will only allow four customers at a time. Entry numbers to the museum will also be limited so you might have to queue.Joseph McKenzies photography at the McManusStill, it will be worth it. To celebrate its reopening, two new exhibitions have just opened. Time and Tide: The Transformation of the Tay looks at the importance of the river in the continuing story of the city, while A Love Letter to Dundee: Joseph McKenzie Photographs - celebrates McKenziersquos evocative and nostalgic black and white images of Dundee as it once was.Visit mcmanusfor more detailsVA Dundee, DundeeStill a few days to wait. The VA reopens its doors on Thursday. Pre-booked timed entry is now required, and social distancing measures and one-way systems have been introduced. But on the plus side the Tatha restaurant will reopen, as will the shop. As the ground floor cafeacute has closed, the Tatha will also offer cafe and takeaway options.And along with the regular galleries, the museum reopens with a new exhibition celebrating the work of Mary Quant, the first international retrospective of the revolutionary fashion designer. As far as we know wearing a mini skirt is not a requirement for entrance. Just as well. Some of us donrsquot have the legs for it.If yoursquore really keen, of course, you could double up with a trip to the Dovecot Studios in Edinburgh where the current exhibition Mid-Century Modern also focuses on Quant along with Terence Conran.Visit vam.ac.uk dundeeto book ticketsThe Stirling Smith Art Gallery and Museum, StirlingAh, The Smith. There is no museum in Scotland Irsquove spent more time in over the years. Having just reopened, it will now be accessible from Thursday to Sunday, am to pm, with a one-way system in operation. No booking necessary.The Stirling Story exhibition continues to occupy its main exhibition space. Artist and collector Thomas Stuart Smith bequeathed his own work and collection to the museum and it forms the heart of The Man Who Could Paint Anything: The Legacy of Thomas Stuart Smith in gallery two, supplemented by donations by subsequent benefactors. title: face-coverings-scotlands-schools-explained-guidance-say
story: Pupils across Scotland will have to wear face coverings in schools from next week,the Scottish Government has confirmed.The updated guidance comes off the back of new public health advice, including World Health Organisation guidelines.So who has to wear a mask  And is it mandatory Here, we detail out everything you need to know:Who should now wear coverings In secondary schools, adults and all pupils moving around the school, such as in corridors and communal areas, where physical distancing is dficult to maintain.However, like in shops and other indoor spaces where masks are mandatory, the Scottish Government accepts there will be some exceptions - including people with certain health conditions.When will this come into force The new guidance will apply from Monday, August .Will schools provide coverings Nicola Sturgeon said plans will be in place for schools to provide extra coverings, to ensure no-one goes without a covering who wants one.Concerns were raised over a lack of social distancing in schoolsWhat about on school transport The new guidance says that all children aged five and over should wear a face covering on dedicated school transport. This is now brought into line with the public transport guidance.What about primary school children With the exception of school buses as outlined above, the new guidance in schools only applies to secondary school pupils.Do they need to be worn in class While staff and students can continue to wear face coveringsthey wish to, they will not generally be necessary in the classroom.This is because there is greater scope for physical distancing and face coverings can have an impact on teaching.However it remains the case that where adults cannot keep m distance and are interacting face-to-face for a sustained period , face coverings should be wornCan a child be excluded for not wearing one It is expected that the guidance will state that pupils should notbe excluded from schoolthey do not wish to wear a face covering.Can someone help my child with their covering Education Secretary John Swinney said:ldquoSchools will be asked to ensure children and young people have clear instructions on how to put on, remove, and store face coverings."Any staff member or pupil will still be able to wear a face covering when they wish to do so."John Swinney confirmed the new guidanceWhy is this being done Mr Swinney added:ldquoThere is increasing evidence that face coverings can provide some protection for the wearer as well as those around them."We also know that some pupils have found it very dficult to physically distance when moving around school, which could increase the risk of transmission of the virus."And on school transport, as on public transport, there can be mixing between dferent age groups."What  was said Mr Swinney said:ldquoWe want to continue to protect what we have achieved in suppressing the virus and re-opening schools, and to do the best for children in schools."Alongside this change to the wearing of face coverings, we need to reinforce the importance of maintaining high standards of cleaning, personal hand and respiratory hygiene and physical distancing, where possible."In situations where there is a local cluster, use of face coverings throughout the day may be required.ldquoThe position will be kept under review to ensure that our approach remains commensurate with the evidence and the levels of transmission in Scotland.

title: six-must-read-scottish-books-headed-tv-film
story: SCOTTISH literature has no shortage of gems, withplots and characters that leap off the page.Over the years, a raft of titles ndash from Treasure Island to Trainspotting and morendash have been adapted for film and television.Here, weve pulled together a list of six Scottish books destined forour screens very soon. How many have you read Eleanor Oliphant Is Completely FineGail Honeymans smash debut novel has been optioned by Reese Witherspoons Hello Sunshine production company with a movie in the works.Set in contemporary Glasgow, Eleanor Oliphant Is Completely Fine is a warm, uplting and incredibly funny tale.Its indomitable eponymous heroine is a social misfit with a traumatic past.Witherspoon has a knack for finding stories that can make the jump from books. She produced the Oscar-nominated films, Gone Girl and Wild, as well as hit TV shows Big Little Lies and Little Fires Everywhere.ConvictionSpeaking of Witherspoon, she chose Conviction by Denise Mina as her Hello Sunshine Book Club pick last December.Although no film deal has been formally announced, theres a good chance that the actor and producer has an eye on bringing the whip-smart thriller ndash where a woman obsessed with true crime podcasts finds herself at the heart of a jet-setting murder mystery ndash to the screen.Jayd Johnson and Ford Kiernan in The Field of Blood - adapted from a Denise Mina novel. Picture: Mark Mainz BBCIn , Minas Paddy Meehan crime novels were adapted to become The Field of Blood, starring Jayd Johnson, David Morrissey and Peter Capaldi, which ran for two series. Her new novel, The Less Dead, is published by Harvill Secker, priced pound..A Dark MatterDoug Johnstonersquos domestic noir series centres on three generations of women ndash Jenny Skelf, her mother Dorothy and daughter Hannah ndash who run a family funeral director business with a sideline as private investigators in Edinburgh.A Dark Matter by Doug JohnstoneThe first novel, A Dark Matter, was published in January and has been optioned as a TV drama by Glasgow-based production company Blazing Grfin, while the second, The Big Chill, is published by Orenda, pricedpound.. Click here to read The Herald Magazine cover story with the author.Blood OrangeThis brilliant debut novel from Harriet Tyce has been optioned by World Productions ndash the makers of Line of Duty and Bodyguard ndash for development into a TV series.The gripping psychological thriller follows a high-flying criminal barrister taking on her first murder case at the same time as her personal le descends into chaos when an affair leads to dark obsession.The Edinburgh-born authors second book, The Lies You Told ndash like Blood Orange it is set in the world of criminal law ndash is published byWildfire, priced pound..Karen PirieITV is making a three-part crime drama based on The Distant Echo, the first in a series of cold case novels by Val McDermid. Set in St Andrews, DCI Karen Pirie is tasked with reopening an investigation into the murder of a teenage barmaid who has become the subject of a provocative true crime podcast.,params: .pushVal McDermids Wire in the Blood Picture: ITVKaren Pirie is another on the World Productions slate and is being adapted by Harlots writer Emer Kenny.A separate series of McDermids books were made into an ITV drama, Wire in the Blood, starring Robson Green as psychological profiler Dr Tony Hill in . Her latest DCI Karen Pirie thriller, Still Le, is published byLittle, Brown, priced pound.Ash MountainIf you were glued to the BBC thriller, The Cry, which starred Jenna Coleman as a young mother whose baby vanishes on a trip to Australia, then look out for Ash Mountain.The Cryrsquos author Helen FitzGeraldrsquos latest novel, published this month, is a deftly written and darkly funny portrait of small-town le as a woman s home to care for her gravely ill father.The TV rights have been snapped up by the new Melbourne-based offshoot of Glasgow production company Synchronicity Films, who also made The Cry. FitzGerald hails from Australia but has lived in Scotland for more than  years, so we can claim her as one of ours.

title: five-epic-munros-adventure-seeking-scots-attempt
story: For those brave enough to accept the challenge, bagging any of Scotlands  Munros is said to be one of the most rewarding experiences around.With breath-taking views at the top, theres no wonder why adventure-seekers take to the climb for hours on end.But with almost  to pick from, it can be a dficult decision.Here, weve pulled together five Munros wed love to try:Braeriach, CairngormsThe Cairngorms are quite dferent to many of other Scottish mountain ranges. Although their summits are mostly rounded and sweeping, they combine to make a vast and wholly unique landscape.The mountains in the Cairngorms rise up out of the remnants of the ancient Caledonian pinewoods and are home to superb wildle and an array of dramatic corries. Braeriach is the third highest mountain in the British Isles and is protected by a long approach walk through a natural tree line.This Munro comes in at km and takes around - hours to complete.Braeriach, Aviemore, PH QTBraeriachBeinn Alligin, TorridonBeinn Alligin, meaning jewelled mountain, is one of three of the Torridon giants and well deserving of its name. This magnicent pair of munros has its own pinnacle ridge called the Horns of Alligin.Sitting on the seaward side of Torridon it has an unmatched viewpoint with glimpses of Skye and the sea to one side, and great peaks on the other side with the Horns providing a stunning foreground.The Munro is around km and takes around - hours.Beinn Alligin Torridon, Alligin, AchnasheenBuachaille Etive Mor, Glen CoeBuachaille Etive Mor is the head of Glen Coe and reigns supreme with its awe-inspiring pyramidal appearance. It is affectionately known by many climbers as the Bookie and, along with its twin Buachaille Etive Beag, are among the most photographed of the Scottish mountains and itrsquos easy to see why!This Munro is perfect for those who want a climb and some incredible views.It is around km and takes around - hours to complete.Aonach Eagach Ridge, A, Ballachulish PH HXLiathach, TorridonAnother of Torridonrsquos three mountains, Liathach is perhaps the finest of them all. Its higher Munro looks almost inaccessible from most directions and even the easiest ascent involves a bit of scrambling but itrsquos certainly worth the effort.Beyond this point the mountain becomes even more dramatic and offers the perfect path for thrill seekers to climb to the top. The hidden north side of the mountain is even more spectacular and is well worth exploring.Slightly longer than the other of Torridonrsquos mountains this walk is around .km and takes around - hours.Achnasheen, IV ETLiathachSgurr nan Gillean, SkyeMany regard Sgurr nan Gillean as being the finest peak on Skye and it is one of the more dficult on this list. Even the easiest ascent on the southeast ridge is a pretty tough scramble ndash the other two ridges venturing into the realm of rock climbing.It appears fairly dramatic from Sligachan but this actually conceals much of the mountainrsquos finest features and its only upon a closer visit to Coire a Bhasteir that the true scale and magnicence of the Pinnacle Ridge reveals this Munrorsquos true stature.This walk is around km and takes roughly  to  hours to complete.Skye, IV SW

title: coronavirus-maskne-seven-ways-look-skin-wearing-masks
story: Facemasks are gradually becoming the new norm in our everyday lives with the coverings helping protect us and those around us.However, people wearing face coverings every day have been noticing that they have started to break out in acne, rashes and skin irritations.Have you had more breakouts since you started wearing a mask We have spoken to Dermalogica skin care expert and beautician Ashley Richards to find out why this happens and how you can protect your skin.What is ldquomaskne Maskne occurs when sweat, oil and bacteria are trapped on your skin while wearing a mask, creating the perfect breeding ground for breakouts.What causes it Maskne is caused by friction, rubbing, and occlusion of the skin by outside forces.Wearing a mask can trap dirt, oil, swear and humidity around the skin.Friction and irritation from the mask pushes bacteria into the skin, which creates micro-tears, and allows the bacteria and dirt to enter the skin more easily.This will lead to blackheads and whiteheads along the bridge of your nose, cheeks and chin. Masks can trigger ious types of skin irritationsand redness .How can you combat maskne There isnrsquot a prevention for maskne, as we need to continue wearing our masks, but there are ways that you can help combat the issues.Skin Care routineIf you want to combat the impact of maskne then having a good skincare routine is essential.It is just as important to cleanse your skin before wearing a mask as it is to cleanse after wearing a mask.To help your skin heal, Ashley would recommend using a squalane or balm cleanser so help remove make-up, dirt and debris.However,you are experiencing chapped, irritated skin or suffer from sensitivity then a gel based cleanseradvised.Dermalogicarsquos UltraCalming Cleanser helps to calm and cool sensitised irritated skin.ExfoliatingExfoliating is key to clear clogged pores and remove dead skin cells which will help reduce the impact of maskne.There are thousands of dferent types of exfoliators available from chemical, physical and masks but it is always important to follow the recommended application and how often you should use the product.Over-exfoliating your skin can compromise your skins barrier , damage the skins capillaries and dehydrate the skin.Ingredients such as glycolic acid, lactic acid and salicylic acid are great exfoliating athelping fight breakouts.Spot treatmentsUsing targeted spot treatments with ingredients such as salicylic acid and benzoyl peroxide will help remove dead skin cells and decongest pores.Hyaluronic AcidsHyaluronic acid can hold , times its weight in water - so it is like a magnet for moisture.,params: .pushUsing hyaluronic acid regularly will leave the skin feeling super-soft, radiant and reduce the appearance of fine lines and wrinkles.Hyaluronic acid has antibacterial properties meaning it will help soothe and protect chapped, irritated skin.FoundationsOpt for tinted moisturisers rather than a heavy foundation or go bare faced to help cause less clogging in your pores - but donrsquot forget your SPF!MoisturisersHeavier moisturisers will sit on the skin for longer due to the humidity of wearing the mask which can cause further clogging and irritation of the skin.However, donrsquot want to stop using a moisturiser all together as our skin still requires hydration and moisture.Instead try using a light and soothing moisturise such as Charlotte Tilburyrsquos Magic Cream light.Chapped SkinFor those suffering from chapped skin try using a physical barrier cream such as Dermalogicarsquos Barrier Repair.Barrier Repair shields against environmental pollution and helps forty sensitive skin with a damaged barrier.

title: coronavirus-mobile-testing-unit-hawick---know
story: A MOBILE-TESTING unitwill run in Hawick for six days, according to NHS Borders.It comes following an outbreak in the townlinked to three businesses.The testing unit will operate from tomorrowuntil Wednesday, September .It will be based in the Teviotdale Leisure Centre car park on Mansfield Road, with tests available between pm-pm.An NHS Borders spokesperson said: "The MTU can only take a limited number of people each day so it is essential that only people with COVID- symptoms book a test."Other household members must self-isolate but should not be tested unless they too are showing any symptoms."The symptoms of COVID- are a high temperature or fever a new continuous cough or a loss of or change in sense of smell or taste."Tests, which must be booked in advance, can be arranged by visiting this websiteor calling  .The new unit will run alongside the existing facility in Galashiels Netherdale car park, which will operate betweenam and pm.If travellingto a mobile unit is not possible, people can arrange for a home test kit to be posted through their door.NHS Borders jointdirector of public health, Tim Patterson, said: "I realise that people in Hawick will have concerns about the virus as a result of this outbreak."Unfortunately this can lead to the circulation of unsubstantiated rumours, especially on social media."I would like to re-iterate that it is crucial for everyone in the community to follow our advice and avoid speculation and rumour about the outbreak."Dr Patterson added: "In terms of schools, all education settings in Hawick are currently safe places for children to learn."Unless your child has been asked to self-isolate by NHS Borders Test and Protect team they should attend school as normal."However it remains vital that no child attends schoolthey are displaying any COVID- symptoms."At the time of publication, a total of nine new cases of coronavirus have been recorded in the Borders in recent days,bringing the regions total title: coronavirus-scotland-book-covid-test-testing-centres
story: In the last week, demands for Covid testing in Scotland have surged.The First Minister suggests some Scots have had trouble trying to book coronavirus tests over the weekend due to a "major spike" in demand, which resulted in technical issues.Butyou are experiencing symptoms, how do you get a test  Heres everything you need to know.When should you take a test If you think you are experiencing symptoms of coronavirus, you should take a test. A test should be taken within the first three days of showing symptoms, but testing is effective until day five.You wonrsquot normally be tested after day  unless itrsquos for a specic reason. This will be agreed on a case-by-case basis.Who is eligible for a test Anyone with symptoms of coronavirus should be tested. You can book a test for either yourself,someone you care for ora child in your care.Key workers, and anyone in their household with symptoms, can access testing through their employer in the first instance and will be given priority.For more information on key worker priority, visit NHS Inform.Where can I get tested in Scotland Currently, there are testing sites at Glasgow, Edinburgh, Aberdeen and Prestwick airports, and in Perth and Inverness at the University of the Highlands and Islands campuses.There are also home testing kits available, which are delivered and collected by Amazon and Royal Mail. You can order one here.How do I book a Covid- test in Scotland There are several ways to get tested for Covid- in Scotland.You can have a home testing kit delivered to your home, or attend one of the testing sites.To book a test, you are asked to complete a self-help guide, which can be found online, to checkyou are eligible. If you cant access the form online, you can callthe coronavirus helpline on   .What does the Covid test involve The coronavirus tests involves taking a swab of the inside of your nose and the back of your throat. This is done using a long cotton bud.When will I get test results According to NHS Inform, results are issued to whoever booked the test and are fed back into public health records.They are sent by text to your mobile phone and should be with you within  hours.

title: scottish-borders-council-backs-20mph-speed-limit-trial
story: DRIVERS will face mph speed limits in  towns and villages after Scottish Borders Councilformally backed the move.Elected members approved the -month trial during the full council on August .The changes have been welcomed by campaigners from Stow Community Council and Stow Community Trust.Ross Murphy, a member of Stow Community Council, said: "We hope this trial will improve road safety through the village and make it a better environment for children, pedestrians and cyclists to move around and stay active."The pilot project will receive pound. million of funding from the Spaces for People programme, which is funded by the Scottish Government.Grace Murray, of Stow Community Trust, said: "We are absolutely delighted. During the coronavirus lockdown we noticed how much local people were enjoying walking in and around Stow and enjoying the spaces we have here.ldquoThe mph trial should encourage them to continue to do so."A lot of people from across Stow are positive about the trial and enthusiastic about embracing it."It will hopefully lead to less use of cars and more active travel.":My Borders village is a death trap because of speeding motoristsThe new speed limits, applying to existing mph roads, will be brought into effect between October and December, with a report being issued to the council after a year. The report will contain guidance on whether the new limits should be kept in place.Trunk roads which run through towns and villages will not be included in the project, meaning the following routes will not be affected: the A, A south of Galashiels, A Melrose Bypass, A and A. However, talks are ongoing with Transport Scotland.Councillor Gordon Edgar, SBCrsquos executive member for roads and infrastructure, said: "Since we announced the Spaces for People programme in the Scottish Borders, there has been considerable discussion about the ious projects, in particular the mph pilot in our towns and villages."Itrsquos worth reiterating that this is a trial but has the potential to help our communitiesrsquo lead healthier lestyles, which is why we want to work with Sustrans Scotland to try out these new measures."Advanced notication will be provided to the public ahead of the new mph limit being introduced in their communities."A full list of the towns and villages getting the mph limit can be found by visiting: www.scotborders.gov.uk mph

title: borders-pensioner-needed-foodbank-high-vet-fee
story: SOME pet owners in Peeblesshire are relying on foodbank support because of hefty veterinary bills.Last week the Peeblesshire Newspublished a letter from PDSA, the UKrsquos leading veterinary charity, in which the organisation appealed for help with its fundraising campaign.But now the charity has been criticised by some of the newspapers readers, who point out that PDSA refuses to provide free pet care in the Borders.A source told the Peeblesshire Newsthat the Peebles Citizens Advice Bureau has been forced to make foodbank referrals for cash-strapped pet owners.The manager of Peebles CAB, Gill Westwood, has since confirmed this, adding that pet owners from the Borders have been turned down for help by PDSA when giving an EH postcode.Ms Westwood said: ldquoI had one pensioner who came to me as we make referrals for the foodbank.ldquoI asked her why she needed help and she told me she had used all her pension to pay for a vet bill as the charity couldnrsquot help her.ldquoPeople who are financially struggling need help from this charity and they are simply not getting it.ldquoI know of other families who have been in a similar situation and had no choice but to ask for help from the foodbank.Ms Westwood said she has written to PDSArsquos chief executive, but to no avail.One local source, who does not want to be named, accused PDSA of being ldquounethical by asking people to fundraise in an area where the charity does not offer a free service.The woman said: ldquoI was upset last week to see the letter from PDSA asking local folk to fundraise for them as they refuse to provide a service in the Borders.ldquoI know that some people have had to go to foodbanks as they canrsquot afford vet fees on their benefits.ldquoPDSA have a charity shop in Galashiels and I think local people think they are helping their fellow Borderers with their vet bills whereas, in fact, evenyou go up to Edinburgh,you give a Borders postcode theyrsquoll turn you away.ldquoI think the charity needs to think carefully about where they raise funds and where they provide services.The Peeblesshire Newscontacted PDSA, which said it provides ldquolow cost treatment schemes in the Borders.A PDSA spokesperson said: ldquoWe would dearly love to help every pet owner who needs support.ldquoBut sadly, as a charity with limited funding, itrsquos simply not always possible.ldquoIn order to have the biggest possible impact on pet wellbeing, we build and run Pet Hospitals in towns and cities where the need is greatest.ldquoCurrently there are  such hospitals in the UK, from Aberdeen to Plymouth. In many smaller communities we work with private vet practices to help provide low cost vet treatment through our PDSA Pet Care scheme.ldquoThere are several practices in the Scottish Borderssigned up to this scheme, which includes cover in Galashiels.ldquoPDSA receives no government funding, and our services cost more than pound million a year to run, helping . million people and providing over . million treatments.ldquoWe currently operate  charity shops across the UK to help pay for these vital services. So we are enormously grateful to our supporters and clients, who help to fund our services.

title: drivers-slam-traffic-lights-a72-near-neidpath-castle
story: A SET of traffic lights have been branded an ldquoabsolute joke this week amid claims they take too long to change colour.The lights near the Neidpath corner on the A, west of Peebles, have been the subject of complaints to Scottish Borders Councilsince .And this week, local resident Michael Adams told our sister newspaper the Peeblesshire Newsthat he fears the lights are an accident waiting to happen.ldquoThey must be the most inefficient traffic lights that have ever been put on a road, said Mr Adams, describing the feature as an ldquoabsolute joke.Mr Adams, a bakery workshop leader at Garvald West Linton, said the timer on the lights has been adjusted to let cyclists through.But he believes an accident will soon be caused, with "up to " frustrated drivers attempting to pass cyclists on the narrow road on some occasions.ldquoThe traffic lights at Neidpath have caused frustration ever since they were installed, he said, adding: ldquoThey are unfit for purpose and when it rains they are laughable.Mr Adams said he has emailed officers at the council, asking them to carry out a study.ldquoI know itrsquos not a major problem, especially in these challenging times, but you would think thatthey can put five people standing in front of a refuse centre, they could get a couple of guys to do a survey to see how useless the lights are, Mr Adams said.He added: ldquoIf the sensors worked correctly then it doesnrsquot matteryoursquore on a bike or articulated lorry.ldquoI waited for ages as the cars had gone through, then as I moved away the lights changed, but when I got around the corner there were no vehicles at the other side.ldquoWhoever installed them should be made to come back and fix them. Itrsquos our money that paid for them.Motorist David Wilson echoed the frustration expressed by Mr Adams.Mr Wilson said: ldquoI travel to my work on this road. There can be four cars waiting, three cars go through, and the lights go back to red.ldquoOr you can wait up to six minutes for the lights to go green at am most mornings.An SBC spokesperson said: ldquoThe set of signals are checked by our maintenance contractor on a regular basis due to the complex nature of them, however it is challenging to achieve a timing balance which suits both vehicle drivers and cyclists.ldquoWe have instructed our maintenance contractor to attend on site to check that everything is working as it should be.

title: coronavirus-symptom-check-child-covid-just-back-to-school-cold
story: SCOTLAND has seen a surge in demand for coronavirus testing since theto schools.Nicola Sturgeon revealed yesterday the number of children under  being tested for COVID- in Scotland has soared eight-fold since the middle of July.The First Minister added that in the last week alone, , children aged two to  were tested ndash but only had a positive result.It comes as parents have been worried about the impact of schools on the spread of the coronavirus.Its important to only book a #coronavirustest through #TestAndProtectyou:# work in a sector such as healthcare, where staff are tested# have been asked to by an @NHSScotlandcontact tracer# have any of the below symptomsLearn more about Test and Protect ##mdash Scottish GovernmentAugust , But when should children be tested Ms Sturgeon stressed that parents should not automatically seek a Covid test for cold-like symptoms such as a runny nose.She said: ldquoWhile itrsquos understandable that parents in particular want to err on the side of caution, itrsquos also important to remember the symptoms of Covid that trigger the need for a test: a new persistent cough, a fever, a loss or change in sense of taste or smell.ldquoOther title: coronavirus-four-new-cases-identified-hawick
story: A FURTHER four COVID- cases are being linked to a cluster in Hawick.A total of  people have now tested positive for the virus in the Borders in the past week.A spokesperson for NHS Borders said: "None of the cases are causing any clinical concern."Test and protect staff are continuing to contact anyone who may be affected, with close contacts being advised to self-isolate and being given appropriate advice."It is essential that everyone follows the Scottish Government guidance and public health advice available at NHS Inform."Remember the FACTS that will help all of us to stay safe and protect each other as well:Face coverings in enclosed spacesAvoid crowded placesClean hands and surfaces regularlyTwo metre distancing andSelf-isolate and book a testyou have symptoms."

title: irn-bru-no-longer-scotlands-popular-food-brand---
story: IRN-BRU has been knocked off the top spot in the competition to be Scotlandrsquos most popular food brand, according to reports.The made-from-girders brand hasbeen topped by Grahamrsquos The Family Dairy, which overtook the Barrrsquos drink for the first time.The status is calculated by Kantarrsquos lsquoBrand Footprintrsquo metrics, which rank businesses according to which products are chosen off the shelf most often and by the most shoppers.Grahams have topped Irn-Bru in the findingsGrahamshas reported that sales of butter alone have doubled during lockdown.The companycame out on top of the likes of Tunnockrsquos, Tennentrsquos and Baxters.The Timesreports that Grahamrsquos also came ninth place in global brands bought in Scotland, beating Birds Eye, Pepsi, Lurpak and more.Managing director Robert Graham said: ldquoWe are absolutely delighted to be named Scotlandrsquos most chosen brand."We are grateful to all our customers for choosing Scottish dairy products from our family business, rather than our international competitors.

title: borders-pet-week-can-give-jet-home
story: THIS weeks pet of the week from Borders Pet Rescue is Jet.The charity said: "Jet is looking for a special home. She is a seven-and-a-half-year-old Border Collie. Coming from a farm, Jet is used to living in a kennel so she has never been in a home."She was underweight when she arrived but with  meals a day she has put on two kg already since being with us."She is currently receiving treatment for an old leg injury and is doing well on the treatment."Jet is a nervous but friendly, sweet girl who needs a home where she can gradually get used to being in a house and getting used to all the new experiences that come with being a pet."She is looking for a home where she will have direct access to a secure garden which will help with her toilet training."Jet is looking for a quiet home without children."She is ok with other dogs so she could live with a calm dog. Jet has not been around cats and has as yet has not been cat tested."Visit: www.borderspetrescue.orgfor more information.

title: scottish-borders-council-issues-face-mask-guidance-schools
story: SCOTTISH Borders Council has issued face mask guidance for all high school pupils.Face masks will become mandatory for secondary school students when moving around and when in communal areas from Monday.Masks are also mandatory for children aged five or older when using dedicated school transport.A letter, sent to the parents of school children by the local authority, reads: ldquoFace coverings will not generally be necessary in the classroom as there is greater scope for physical distancing and face coverings can have an impact on learning and teaching.ldquoHowever, it remains the case that where adults cannot keep two metre distance and are interacting face-to-face for a sustained periodface coverings should be worn. In addition, staff and students can continue to wear face coverings in any classroomthey wish to.ldquoScottish Borders Council has carefully planned theof pupils to our schools using all guidance provided by the Scottish Government.ldquoThis latest update from the Government is based on the latest scientic and public health advice and we will be putting it in place across our schools.ldquoPlease ensure your child wears a face covering while moving around the school campus,they attend a secondary school, and at all times on school transport they travel to and from school on a bus, coach or taxi.Parents have also been asked to make sure masks cover the nose, mouth and chin, and to wash reusable face masks every day in  degree centigrade or boiling water.The council has not provided any guidance on the styles of masks which will be permitted, indicating there are no unorm restrictions, but inidual schools may wish to set their own style guidelines.

title: live-borders-reopening-dates-swimming-pools-gyms
story: SWIMMERS will start ing to Live Borders pools next week.Galashiels Swimming Pool reopens on Tuesday , with other pools following later as part of a phased approach for the coming days and weeks.First Minister Nicola Sturgeon allowed pools and gyms to reopen from August .In a statement issued last week, Live Borders CEO Ewan Jackson said he was ldquopleased to share a schedule of dates for the reopening of facilities in the Borders.The full list of datescan be accessed on the Live Borders website.Live Borders has announced that, initially, the pool programmes will consist of lane swimming, club sessions and aquafit classes only.The lsquoLearn to Swimrsquo programmes will restart at a later date.TriFitness facilities in Galashiels are scheduled to reopen on Wednesday . Due to social-distancing guidelines, the capacity will be cut to .Opening hours at sites will be limited to ensure viability and to allow appropriate cleaning.Hawickrsquos Teviotdale Leisure Centre was forced to postpone the reopeningof its pool and gym due to the townrsquos coronavirus outbreak. The facilities, which had been due to reopen on Wednesday, are now scheduled to welcome back users next week.Mr Jackson added: ldquoWe have been managing the pool water carefully during lockdown and are now awaiting the results of microbiological tests to very the pool water is safe for swimming.ldquoWe want our members and customers to have a safe and enjoyable experience when theyto our pools and gyms, and are putting measures in place such as pre-booking, enhanced cleaning, social distancing and greater spacing of equipment to facilitate this.Councillor Euan Jardine, Scottish Borders Councilrsquos executive member for culture and sport, said: ldquoI am delighted that a number of key Live Borders facilities are set to reopen.ldquoA phased approach is being taken to the reopening of these facilities, with the safety of the public and Live Borders staff the highest priority.ldquoI look forward to seeing more of our arearsquos sports facilities opening their doors again in the coming weeks and months.

title: coronavirus-live-borders-halts-reopening-teviotdale-pool
story: THE reopening of a Borders leisure centre has been postponed due to an increase in coronavirus cases in the area.Teviotdale Leisure Centre in Mansfield Road, Hawick, had been scheduled to welcome members back on Wednesday .But following a spate of virus casesin the town, the local leisure trust has pushed back the reopening date by one week.A spokesperson for Live Borders said: "Following the announcement of a small increase in cases of COVID- in Hawick over the weekend, we are taking a cautious and responsible decision and delaying the opening of Teviotdale Leisure Centre Gym scheduled for Wednesday, September ."Our decision to open has always been based on the safety of our customers and staff as the main priority."We will delay the gym opening by one week and the Teviotdale Leisure Centre will now open for the use of both the swimming pool and gym on Wednesday, September  ndash providing the number of cases do not continue to increase."We will continue to review the situation and our position."We know this will disappoint many, but hope you will understand your and our teams safety cannot be compromised."Updates will continue to be issued to keep members up to date."

title: trimontium-trust-appoints-duke-gloucester-patron
story: A TRUST established to manage a Roman fort in the Borders has appointed a member of the royal family as its patron.The Trimontium Trust, which oversees the Roman fort near Newstead, has announced that the Duke of Gloucester will be its new patron, as renovation works at the museum in Melrose begin.John Reid, chairman of the Trimontium Trust said: ldquoIt is a great honour for the trust to have a patron of such high standing.ldquoTrimontium is one of the most important Roman sites in the UK and His Royal Highness will help us raise awareness of the importance of the unique Roman and native hillfort heritage in the Scottish Borders, which is home to not only the important Roman site of Trimontium, but one of the highest concentrations of Iron Age hillforts in Europe.Construction work to renovate the museum in Melrosersquos Ormiston Institute is scheduled to start next month.:The Borders woman rowing across the Atlantic in a boat made of plastic bottlesThe pound. million project ndash supported by the National Lottery Heritage Fund , the South of Scotland Economic Partnership , Scottish Borders Counciland Museums Galleries Scotlandndash will include the creation of more display space, a more direct entry into the museum, an improved visitor reception space and the creation of a new, state-of-the-art digital interpretation of the Roman site of Trimontium.The Roman fort was occupied for more than  years from the st to rd centuries AD and at its peak it is believed to have housed up to , people, including more than , soldiers.Key finds made at Trimontium include parade helmets, bronze wine jugs, military equipment , blacksmiths tools and farming implements, human and animal remains, and writing tablets.

title: profile-boost-britains-small-businesses
story: Britainrsquos most inspirational small businesses are being given the chance for a spell in the limelight in a national campaign.From a Nigerian tapas restaurant in Tottenham, run by brother and sister duo Emeka and Ifeyinwa Frederick, to a haberdashery store in Kirkintilloch, Scotland, the Small Biz  will profile some of the UKrsquos best small businesses in the  days building up to Small Business Saturday on December .Now in its eighth year in the UK, the campaign has grown signicantly each year with a record turnout of . million people choosing to shop small on the day last year, generating an estimated poundm.Among the other firms being recognised are a West Midlands dog trainer, a childrens pamper party service in Leighton Buzzard and an online sportswear retailer and support club in Wales for mums who run.ldquoThis yearrsquos Small Business Saturday is going to be the most important one yet, given the phenomenally tough time small businesses have had with the double whammy of Covid- and now a recession, said Michelle Ovens, director of Small Business Saturday UK.ldquoThroughout the crisis the UK has been reminded about what a special and important role small firms play in communities across the UK. The launch of the fabulous Small Biz  highlights the amazing, positive impact these firms have.ldquoItrsquos vital we continue to support small businesses as this crisis continues and wersquore determined to make the  Small Business Saturday bigger and better than ever.Small Business Saturday is back for  on the th December.
